Text: NOAA weather satellites are polar-orbiting satellites developed by NASA for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). They are designed to monitor Earth's climate and environment and provide high-resolution images of Earth's weather patterns from space. The satellite will circle the Earth from North Pole to South Pole 14 times a day, enabling full global coverage every 12 hours.

Weather satellites work like radio systems. The polar-orbiting satellite takes images while it moves over the Earth, broadcasting data back to the ground. Tuning into specific satellite frequencies, ground stations can receive and decode analogue signals.

The NOAA-15 weather satellite (the oldest satellite we have been receiving signals from) launched on May 13, 1998. NOAA-15's mission was to be in space for only 2 years, but it has been circling the Earth in a sun-synchronous orbit for over 23 years.

The first successful Low Earth Orbit weather satellite, TIROS-1, entered orbit on April 1, 1960. Despite plans for a mission duration of 90 days, TIROS-1 lost contact with the ground station on June 15th, 1960, due to an electrical power failure.
Over its short lifespan of 75 days, TIROS-1 captured and transmitted 23,000 photos back to Earth.
In this process, the position of the satellite determines not only the image but also the satellite's broadcasting coverage.
For the first time, it was possible to observe cloud formations and meteorological patterns at a large scale.
